creator: cutebear103@hotmail.com
text:
Tomcat 5.5.17 is running on Linux Enterprise server. The traffic is still 
pretty light. But there is a crash in the APR library once awhile.

hs_err.log contents:

creator: jorton@redhat.com
text:
"Crash in Tomcat" does not necessarily imply "Bug in APR"; this needs to be
diagnosed from the Tomcat perspective first.

You're using Java2D, which as usual is doing invalid accesses to the
output steam. Without APR, you would get issues like getting requests
which are already committed at the beginning of the request, and other
random behavior like that. The solution is to not give direct access
to the Servlet API to the Java2D components (using an intermediate
buffer, etc), or enable the security manager.
creator: remm@apache.org

text:
Is there any related bug report or document/web page I can read to figure out 
exactly what to do? I can certain write a bypassing output stream wrapper, but 
it doesn't seem to do any good if I just simply pass every call to the 
underlying output stream given by Tomcat.
creator: cutebear103@hotmail.com

text:
What can APR do to resist making memory access violations regardless of what
Tomcat hands it in this particular case?  Can it detect this and return an error
rather than SIGSEGV and scuttling the process?
creator: skelter.net@gmail.com

text: *** Bug 40868 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
